Key Arguments: The bill disregards freedom of speech and democratic principles.
It creates an imbalance of power between politicians/journalists and regular citizens.
Excessive fines will lead to restrictive speech policies by digital services.
The government should not define or police truth as it is subjective and ever-changing.
The bill could lead to anti-competitive practices and stifle innovation.
Extraterritorial reach is unworkable and could harm Australia's global standing.
The bill infringes on the implied constitutional freedom of political communication.
Labeling viewpoints as misinformation could harm independent media and public discourse.
The bill is reminiscent of undemocratic regimes and undermines freedom of expression.
Notable Quotes: The bill blatantly disregards our freedom of speech and the democratic principles that underpin our society.
Attempting to discern truth from falsehood is an impossible task, as new information constantly emerges.
The bill's infringement on the implied constitutional freedom of political communication is deeply concerning.
This type of control is reminiscent of undemocratic regimes and undermines Australia's commitment to freedom of expression.
